title: Ticket #5416: master should have a command to query (and wait for) child readiness
description:
In support of #5340, and for testing. it would be nice to have a command that can be sent to the master and it would reply with the readiness states of each of it's children. It would also be nice if the master could delay responding to query until the children had reached a known readiness state or a timeout had expired.

A new command would be added to the master 

    DC_QUERY_READY

The Master would reply to this query with a classad containing a single global readiness attribute and 2 attributes for each child in the daemon list. 

    IsReady    = bool: all non-held daemons are in "Alive" state
    NumDaemons = int:  number of daemons in DAEMON_LIST
    NumAlive   = int:  number of daemons in "Alive" state
    NumStartup = int:  number of daemons in "Startup" state
    NumHold    = int:  number of daemons in "Hold" state
    NumHung    = int:  number of daemons in "Hung" state
    NumDead    = int:  number of daemons in "Dead" state
    # 2 attributes for each daemon in DAEMON_LIST
    <Daemon>_PID = int: PID or 0 if no child process
    <Daemon>     = string: one of the <readiness-state> values
    # 1 optional additional attribute for some daemons in DAEMON_LIST
    <Daemon>_State = string: state reported by the daemon using =DC_SET_READY=

The <Daemon> values will be the names from DAEMON_LIST,

The possible string values for <readiness-state> will be 

    "Alive"  - got a pid and at least 1 alive message from that pid
    "Hung"    - got a pid and at least 1 alive message, but none recently
    "Startup" - started the child, but have not yet got an alive message or decided it hung
    "Dead"    - no pid and not on hold
    "Hold"    - no pid and daemon has been condor_off'd
    "WaitForStartup" - no pid and waiting before starting the daemon
    "WaitForStartupFile" - no pid and waiting before starting the daemon

For daemons that send the master a DC_SET_READY message, the string value sent in this message will be written to a <Daemon>_State attribute, it will be reported as part of the DC_QUERY_READY reply until a change of the <readiness-state> of the daemon clears it. In general, do not expect a daemon that is not in "Alive" state to have a <Daemon>_State attribute.

In addition to the basic query, the DC_QUERY_READY command will have a ClassAd payload, that can be used to specify that the reply should not occur until a desired readiness state has been achieved or a timeout has expired. The attributes to control this will be 

    ReadyRequirements = <readiness-expr>
    WaitTimeout = <max-time-before-reply-in-sec>

When a non-zero timeout is supplied the ReadyRequirements expression will be evaluated against the readiness ad once per second, and the reply will be sent once the WaitTimeout has expired, or ReadyRequirements evaluates to true. So for instance 

    ReadyRequirements = (NumDead > 0) || (IsReady && (STARTD_State =?= "Ready"))
    WaitTimeout       = 60

Will tell the master to reply only once all daemons have sent at least 1 heartbeat, and the Startd has sent "ready", or after 60 seconds have expired.

condor_who -quick will be enhanced to use the new DC_QUERY_READY command, and (possibly?) a new flavor of condor_tool will be created to make it easy to use the query ready command in a script.
remarks:
2015-Nov-25 14:07:18 by johnkn:
Once this feature is in and tested, it should be backported to stable so that can be used in the test suite.

2016-Oct-12 14:47:35 by johnkn:
condor_who has a new argument to support the use of the DC_QUERY_READY message. 

condor_who -wait-for-ready[:<time>] <expr>

When this argument is used, condor_who will scrape the log directory(s) to find the MASTER, and once it knows the master address it will attempt to send a DC_QUERY_READY to the master with <time> as the timeout and <expr> as the Readyness expression. If a readyness ad is returned it will print this in -long form (unless -af or -autoformat is used). 

condor_who -quick
does the same thing, but with a <time> of 0 and an <expr> of TRUE.
